channel.title: NYT > Style
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Please Don’t Make Me Open That Gift in Public
item.description: It’s a time-honored tradition for wedding showers: open your present in front of an audience and express delight. But it seems that the cringe-y (for some) custom is on the decline.

item.title: Are You Ready for Gas Station Sunglasses?
item.description: Wraparound shades are now embraced by celebrities and fashion fiends worldwide.
item.media:credit: Michael Raines for The New York Times

item.title: What Makes a Room Unforgettable?
item.description: Ask the founders of Roman and Williams, who for two decades have designed homes, hotels, restaurants, clubs, galleries, stores, furniture — even birdhouses — bathed in a luxe patina.
item.category: Roman and Williams Buildings and Interiors
item.media:credit: Landon Speers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Roman and Williams founders Stephen Alesch and Robin Standefer pivoted to interior design after working on films. “The stars and producers on these movie sets said, ‘Why don’t our houses look as good as the movie sets?’” she said.

item.title: My Post-Divorce Choice: OkCupid or Petfinder?
item.description: When loving a dog feels much more fraught than loving another man.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: The Voyeur in Repose
item.description: Steven Klein’s sexually charged photography has captivated the fashion world for nearly three decades. His first monograph will be published this month.
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

item.title: Who Wears Crop Tops to the Office?
item.description: Young employees, many of them new to office jobs, are bringing a wardrobe staple usually reserved for the weekends into the workplace.
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Santina Rizzi in the Miami plastic surgery office where she works as a social media manager. “I’m not going to buy clothes specifically for my job,” she said of her fondness for wearing crop tops to work.

item.title: On Twitter, Who Needs a Check Mark When You Can Have a Rat?
item.description: Elon Musk wants Twitter users to pay to be verified. An artist offers a wry alternative.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Dado Ruvic/Reuters

item.title: ‘Co-Conspirators and Playmates From the Get-Go’
item.description: Jennifer Douglas was “avowedly anti-marriage” after her divorce; Kent Shell, too. Until she got down on one knee.
item.media:credit: Paul Barbera for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Douglas and Kent Shell’s wedding, on Sept. 10 in Tivoli, N.Y., “wasn’t just about us, but it was about community and sort of consecrating ourselves to living out loud again,” Mr. Shell said.

item.title: Our Son Committed Us to Wedding Costs We Can’t Afford. Help!
item.description: Without consulting them, a reader’s son agreed to a plan to have his parents split the costs of a lavish wedding with his future in-laws.
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: A Fashion Model With an Activist Streak
item.description: Yves Mathieu-East uses his body as a mural to tell his story of being a Black, queer model, activist and singer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hawgood
item.media:credit: Chad Unger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yves Mathieu-East has modeled for Pyer Moss, Thom Browne and Adidas. In his spare time, he volunteers with numerous charities and fosters pit bulls.

item.title: The Story Behind the Roku Screen Saver
item.description: Instead of streaming a new TV show or movie, some Roku users are in it for the screen saver.
item.dc:creator: Luke Winkie

item.title: Los Angeles Pedestrians Look Forward to Relaxed Jaywalking Law
item.description: “I’m smart enough to know if cars are coming,” said one walker who is glad the old law will come off the books on Jan. 1.
item.dc:creator: Will Higginbotham
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two men cross against the light in downtown Los Angeles.

item.title: A Hamptons Property Fight Over a Black Whaler’s Homestead
item.description: Property tussles in the moneyed enclaves of Long Island are nothing new, but the battle to preserve the homestead of Pyrrhus Concer raises questions of whose history gets to be honored.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Gellman
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brenda Simmons, left, and Georgette Grier-Key in front of a truck that holds the remains of Pyrrhus Concer’s home in the Hamptons.

item.title: Usha Vance Has Helped Her Husband J.D. Vance Chart His Political Path
item.description: The Ohio Senate candidate’s wife, an accomplished lawyer, remains ensconced in the milieu he now rails against.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein and Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Gaelen Morse/Reuters
item.media:description: J.D. and Usha Vance celebrated his Ohio Senate primary victory in May.

item.title: For These New York Farmers, Harvest Time Means High Times
item.description: In fields from Sag Harbor to Ithaca, a new crop ripened this fall: cannabis plants grown for recreational marijuana.
item.dc:creator: John Ortved and Paul Barbera
item.media:credit: Paul Barbera for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the 1930s, the growing of cannabis was all but banned across the United States.

item.title: La rara belleza de un triángulo amoroso
item.description: En una pareja, una línea recta conecta los puntos. Con tres personas en una relación, surgen muchas más configuraciones.
item.dc:creator: Evan Sterrett
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Love Letter: A New Boyfriend or a New Dog?
item.description: After a divorce, which would you choose?
item.dc:creator: Miya Lee

item.title: ‘Design Mom’ Gabrielle Blair Pivots to Politics
item.description: After 16 years of making a name for herself as a blogger and home decor expert, Design Mom has written her manifesto — about reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: Kase Wickman
item.media:credit: Matthew Avignone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabrielle Blair, 48, also known as Design Mom, sits in her study at home in Argentan, France. Her family has been restoring the 17th century house since 2019.

item.title: Where the Sky Meets the Sea: Jennifer Guidi Leans Into Beauty
item.description: The artist’s new show at David Kordansky Gallery reveals her spiritual sensibility and inspires the pleasures of looking.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Curators have increasingly come to recognize the depth and complexity of Jennifer Guidi’s art. “It’s more than it initially appears,” said one museum director.

item.title: Laughter Is the Best Medicine
item.description: Emilie Thompson and Thomas Hart were both interested in the sciences, but it was a comedy show and a shared sense of humor that connected them.
item.dc:creator: Nina Reyes

item.title: An Engagement Party With a Twist
item.description: Morgan Kilpatrick and William Vollers delighted their guests by turning an engagement party into an unexpected wedding ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Block

item.title: Through Sickness, Health and Hurricane Ian
item.description: Weeks before their wedding date, Natalie Rochette and Dillon Etherson scrambled to find a venue after the original place in Southwest Florida was damaged by flooding.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Spencer

item.title: Campaigns Skirt Political Ad Rules by Paying Influencers
item.description: Campaigns are using social media influencers as a way to reach young and diverse voters, a novel and mostly unregulated strategy. Some are even spreading the message through dating apps.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ky’Wuan Dukes, a Johnson C. Smith University student, has worked with a Democratic political action committee to reach young voters with posts on his Instagram account.

item.title: The Internet Still Thinks I’m Pregnant
item.description: When Amy Pittman had a miscarriage, she grieved her loss — and tried to move on. But the internet wouldn’t let her.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Who Is Jennifer Lawrence Now?
item.description: The Oscar-winning “Hunger Games” actress is free from her franchise commitments. But after a brief hiatus from acting, what will she do next?
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Robbie Lawrence for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I obviously cannot relate to risking my life for my country,” Jennifer Lawrence said, “but I can understand, reading ‘Causeway,’ why I’m getting so emotional about somebody who doesn’t feel like they belong anywhere unless they’re on a schedule.”

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Love Drama’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Vogue Mexico Adapts Met Gala Formula for Day of the Dead
item.description: Vogue Mexico on Thursday hosted its third gala celebrating the holiday. “We want this event to be shared globally,” its top editor said.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Alicia Vera for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican designer Benito Santos, a gala sponsor, held a fashion show at the event. Some models wore floral headpieces, an accessory associated with Day of the Dead.

item.title: A Minimalist House for Clutter-Free Living (Despite the Kids)
item.description: A Southern California designer wanted to create a home where “everything gets put away at night” — and she succeeded. Sort of.
item.dc:creator: Tim McKeough

item.title: What Does the End of Yeezy Mean for the Sneakerverse?
item.description: Rampant speculation has entered the market.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: Yeezy shoes made by Adidas displayed at Laced Up, a sneaker resale store in Paramus, N.J., in October.

item.title: Your Challenge? Turn an Old Rug Into a New Fall Jacket.
item.description: In “Upcycle Nation,” a fashion competition premiering this week on Fuse TV, contestants reimagine previously used items as wearable designs.
item.dc:creator: Ruth La Ferla
item.media:credit: Sabrina Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonas King, a contestant on “Upcycle Nation,” a new show focusing on repurposing and upcycling old items.

item.title: The Times Wants to Hear Your ‘Tiny Gratitude Stories’
item.description: Tell us in 100 words or less what you are thankful for in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Daniel Salmieri

item.title: Glimpses of Life with the Sea Clown Sailing Circus Troupe
item.description: A photographer embedded with the Sea Clown Sailing Circus on the troupe’s journeys through the Mediterranean. Here’s what he saw.
item.dc:creator: Nicola Zolin

item.title: Is Lace for Men the Latest Fashion Trend?
item.description: The gauzy fabric is not just for women’s lingerie and dresses anymore. Guys are flirting with the see-through material.
item.dc:creator: Julie Lasky
item.category: Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lace has broken free of gender barriers. Kid Cudi attended the CFDA Fashion Awards last year in a lace gown.

item.title: Does a Blazer for Everywhere Exist?
item.description: A reader is searching for a blazer that is not too fancy to be worn with sneakers and jeans.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press

item.title: What Machine Gun Kelly and Megan Fox Wore Last Week
item.description: Top outfits from the Time100 Next dinner, a Diwali gala and Creative Time cocktails.
item.dc:creator: Denny Lee
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Megan Fox, in Maison Yeya, at the Time100 Next gala.
